body:
Hi, thanks for the response.

I'm using grpcio 1.1.0.
I can reproduce the problem every time by starting greeter_server.py and then greeter_client.py. The client receives the response and terminates, and then the CPU load of the server jumps to 100%. It still responds to requests after that.

Profiling results with yappi:
```
   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        1    0.000    0.000   28.673   28.673 threading.py:743(CleanupThread.run)
        1    0.000    0.000   28.673   28.673 _server.py:662(_serve)
        1    0.001    0.001    0.906    0.906 greeter_server.py:30(<module>)
        5    0.004    0.001    0.821    0.164 __init__.py:29(<module>)
        1    0.004    0.004    0.811    0.811 __init__.py:16(<module>)
        2    0.000    0.000    0.596    0.298 __init__.py:3019(_call_aside)
        1    0.000    0.000    0.596    0.596 __init__.py:3036(_initialize_master_working_set)
       40    0.000    0.000    0.591    0.015 __init__.py:682(WorkingSet.add_entry)
       64    0.007    0.000    0.588    0.009 __init__.py:2003(find_on_path)
       30    0.000    0.000    0.563    0.019 __init__.py:1977(_by_version_descending)
```
Running the server with `time` for 30 seconds shows that most of the time is spent in kernel space:
```9.79s user 18.60s system 93% cpu 30.403 total```

It looks like it is spinning on a lock or something while waiting for new events.

I tried with a fresh Lubuntu installation to rule out my system. CPU usage goes to 100% with Python 2.7 and 3.5, but not with 3.6
I am able to reproduce this problem with Python 2.7. @mehrdada have you yet taken a look?
I did a quick test on macOS/Python2.7 and was unable to observe the behavior. I am able to reproduce this on Python2.7 and Python3.5 on Ubuntu 16.04. I did not observe this behavior on Python 3.6.
I looked further into the issue and it seems it is fixed in the latest master (86e9f3564a9ab05ac14d81628167bc359ca56694). @alexf91 can you please test to see if you can observe the issue on master?
Yes, master is working fine. Only checked with Python 2.7 though.

@alexf91: thank you for looking. How severely are you affected by this problem?

We believe that a release will be cut from (what today is) `master` in less than six weeks.
I'm not affected at all. I just started using grpc and can use my own build for development.
I tried Ubuntu 16.04/Python 3.5 as well and the issue does not seem to affect master.

Given what's been said so far, I think the right thing for this bug is to leave it until the 1.2.0 release and then close it. While it's definitely weird we're not currently aware of it being a large problem for anyone. We're curious but finding the root cause would be a big investment into [somatic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Somatic_(biology)) code.

I believe I've run into this issue when attempting to port a small system to gRPC, which is going to prevent me from making further progress on that. Any other info on an ETA for a patched stable release?

1.2.0 ought to be released in about a month now.

On Mon, Feb 27, 2017, 18:59 Scott Bezek <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I believe I've run into this issue when attempting to port a small system
> to gRPC, which is going to prevent me from making further progress on that.
> Any other info on an ETA for a patched stable release?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/9688#issuecomment-282927396>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AG8bpi35UnhiPGSDsvcwuWt6q0Ep4cwWks5rg413gaJpZM4L_mV_>
> .
>

the same problem: run in docker with centos, python 2.7, pip installed grpcio(1.1.3), not found in grpcio-v0.15. why must use thread pool in grpcio(1.1.3)? why not make it as optional param....  sorry for Chinglish...

@kernelpig: the thread pool was made a required, positional parameter of server construction because we believed that we always wanted applications to have that level of control over how servers serviced concurrent RPCs.

I can reproduce the behaviour with grpcio 1.1.5 on Python **3.6.0** (compiled locally) on Ubuntu 16.04.

Master is not affected.
I have the same problem
@nathanielmanistaatgoogle thank you for your answer
@sofo23 master has solved this problem. I tried it in python 2.7, it's ok.

@kernelpig Thank you for your reply.

 I try to install using this command grpcio using this command:
pip install git+git://github.com/grpc/grpc.git@86e9f3564a9ab05ac14d81628167bc359ca56694
Is it the right way to install the master branch? It takes soo much time.
Weirdly, we are seeing this issue on Ubuntu + Python 3.5.2 up to grpc 1.2.0rc2 but 86e9f35 appears to be working great.
@egoldschmidt: if it's happening for you in a reproducible and deterministic way with 1.2._anything_ we'd love to hear about it in as much detail as you can share.

Call me crazy but I think I have a repro case here: https://github.com/egoldschmidt/grpc-cpu-test

I threw it together quickly so apologies if I'm missing something!

I'm confirming that I can repro the problem consistently with v1.1.0, v1.1.3, v1.2rc1, v1.2rc2 all installed through pip. I'm running Ubuntu 16.04 and python 2.7.12. As soon as one request completes, a single CPU core maxes out to 100% and stays there until I manually restart the server.
we can still reproduce this with latest grpc release v1.2.0 - sadly keeps us from using grpc in production

Is there something wrong with the wheels on pypi?

### Python 2.7.13 on Arch Linux:
I've built the tagged 1.1.0 and 1.2.0 versions, and both work fine. Then I built it from the 1.2.0 source archive on pypi, which also works fine.
The load only goes up when I use the wheels from pypi.

### Python 3.6.0 on Arch Linux
v1.2.0 works fine when built locally, but fails when installed through pip.

I've also created a repository, which automates checking a certain commit: https://github.com/alexf91/grpc-cpu-test/tree/master
I've initially created it to run with git bisect, but since I can't reproduce the bug with my own builds, I haven't isolated a commit.

I've been experimenting with this and might have a stack trace that could be helpful. 

`#0  0x00007f384ffdfaed in poll () at ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S:81`
`#1  0x00007f384c978526 in pollset_work (exec_ctx=0x7f3849956380, pollset=0x1d48cc0,
    worker_hdl=0x7f3849956310, now=..., deadline=...) at src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_poll_posix.c:984`
`#2  0x00007f384c995369 in grpc_completion_queue_next (cc=0x1d48bd0, deadline=...,
    reserved=reserved@entry=0x0) at src/core/lib/surface/completion_queue.c:429`
`#3  0x00007f384c93bbe1 in __pyx_pf_4grpc_7_cython_6cygrpc_15CompletionQueue_2poll (
    __pyx_v_deadline=<optimized out>, __pyx_v_self=0x7f384fd630d0)
    at src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/cygrpc.c:10417`
`#4  __pyx_pw_4grpc_7_cython_6cygrpc_15CompletionQueue_3poll (__pyx_v_self=0x7f384fd630d0,
    __pyx_args=<optimized out>, __pyx_kwds=<optimized out>)
    at src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/cygrpc.c:10277`
`#5  0x00007f3850c9ae8e in _PyCFunction_FastCallDict (func_obj=0x7f384b3edb40,
    args=0x7f3844001258, nargs=<optimized out>, kwargs=kwargs@entry=0x0)
    at Objects/methodobject.c:231`

I think that python executable and grpc executable are waiting on the same semaphore to unlock and it's causing them both to just spin, deadlocked.

`  3    Thread 0x7fded4e59700 (LWP 166) "python" 0x00007fdedb13eaed in poll () at ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S:81`
`  2    Thread 0x7fdecffff700 (LWP 173) "python" sem_wait () at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/sem_wait.S:85`
`  1    Thread 0x7fdedc47a700 (LWP 164) "python" 0x00007fdedb140893 in select () at ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S:81`

Also the packages that are built when you pip install from the source versus when you pip install from pypi are binary different. I can give you a list of files that are different between the two packages if that would help.

When I install the pypi package, src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_poll_posix.c is used by src/core/lib/surface/completion_queue.c, however, when I build src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_poll_linux.c is used. Not sure why or what the difference is yet.

@dgn: on what platform are you working?

@egoldschmidt, @assiotis, @alexf91, @timmyzaid: thank you for digging so deeply into this!

To sum up my results:
manylinux builds have the issue, others don't (at least not on my machine). I've built the current master in the manylinux Docker container, and it also has the issue.

The reason why I did not see this issue with Python 3.6 when I reported this, is because there was no manylinux build for 1.1.0 and Python 3.6, so this was built from the source archive.

I'm not sure what your build system looks like but I wonder if `GRPC_POLL_STRATEGY` is set on it which is causing the event engine to always be the posix version? Outside of that, I'm pretty sure a debug build can be built with that set to `poll` to be able to reproduce it from source.
